Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Dynamics of Polyatomic Molecules: New Probes for New Insights
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Arthur G. Suits of Wayne State University and his graduate student, undergraduate student and post-doctoral researcher colleagues are investigating the physical and chemical properties of important small molecules. The ultimate goal of the work by Professor Suits and his group is to develop a better understanding of the reactivity of atmospherically important or chemically interesting molecules. The young researchers working on this project will receive training in state-of-the art methods from a leader in the field of physical chemistry.

Prof. Suits and his research group will use imaging of spin-polarized hydrogen atoms produced from excited polyatomic molecules to unravel the details of the photochemistry of important molecules, including water and methane. The results from work like this will help scientists understand the photochemistry of planetary atmospheres. In further experiments, the Suits Group will use a chirped-pulse, uniform flow spectrometer to study the reaction kinetics of unstable chemical intermediates, including exotic species like HOONO. The goal of this study is to understand the important role that these fleeting intermediates play in complex, real-world reacting systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is directed to develop new experimental methods and approaches to leverage the powerful methods of chemical dynamics to reveal new insights into the reaction dynamics of polyatomic molecules and the properties and dynamics of excited states and transient radicals and reaction intermediates.

In an ongoing series of experiments we have studied how angular momentum polarization (specifically how electrons move within an atom) produced in photodissociation can reveal the history of the dissociation process. This directly reflects aspects of bond-breaking that are at the heart of chemistry.

We also develop new approaches and new instruments with which to study elementary chemical reactive processes. One of these is the powerful combination of chirped-pulse microwave spectroscopy with uniform supersonic flows. Chirped-pulse microwave spectroscopy is a new technique that allows one to obtain the complete rotational spectra for many molecules across a wide range in a millionth of a second. However, it requires many sample molecules at low temperature. Uniform supersonic flows provide a high-density low temperature environment perfectly matched for the chirped-pulse approach. We have shown we can combine these techniques as a new way to study photodissociation and reaction. We have applied this to study photodissociation of reactive radical species with product isomer selectivity.

In another aspect of the project, we have developed a new approach to analyze finite-sliced velocity images from photodissociation or reaction. This technique, termed “Finite slice analysis” or FinA, gives unprecedented resolution in these studies.

Thr broader impacts of this work include the development of the FinA program, which is broadly shared with other teams working in velocity map imaging, and with training the next generation of scientist from a diverse pool. Our team is an international group that includes four women and members who come from all over the world, from Sri Lanka and China to the Europe and Africa.
